div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Newspaper, Established 1850
Editor & Meager : R SNELLING.
Prlce; Ono Piastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBBR 18, 1905.
FRANCE AND SYRIA.

During his recent visit to France H.B. Mgr. Hawayek, the Maronite Patriarch, appears to have accorded interviews to several French journalists in which he stated that the Maronite population of the Lebanon, whatever its sympathies with other nations, could not forget that it owed its present comparative freedom and happiness to French intervention, and had no idea of exchanging a French for a German protectorate. Whether the Patriarch would have spoken with the same fervour during M. Combes' regime is doubtful That vigorous anti-clerical did not realize that the French protectorate over the Eastern Christians was from every point of view a “valuable asset,” and the studied incivility with which the Patriarch himself was treated on one occasion might have cost the Republic dear. Fortunately for French interests, M. Combes' successor has realised that anti-clericalism J is ' not an article for exportation, and his policy has done much to heal tho sores left by his predecessor’s rather unwise neglect. None the less the position of France in Syria is by no means so strong as in former years. The Germans, though they have not extended their operations to the Lebanon, are extending their influence in Palestine to the Damascus region. The Jewish colonies in the Holy Land are more German than French in origin and sympathies, and Russia, France's ally in Europe, had made formidable progress until her prestige was overthrown by Japan. Ameri- can influence, though not directly political, mast affect local politics. Education in Syria is largely in American hands, and the Ameri- can College at Beyrout is now a serious rival of the Jesuit schools and colleges. British in- fluence, always strong among the Druses and Protestants of Syria, has gained fresh strength since the young Syrians took to visiting Egypt in search of an honest government and lucrative employment, and our commercial interests in Palestine and Syria are far superior to those of any other nation. It is for France to decide whether her influeuce in Syria shall survive or not, and on her decision much depends, for, if France gradually withdraws from the Near East to concentrate her attention on her new African Empire, there can be no doubt that her great European rival will make every effort to take her place. British statesmen hare long looked forward complacently to a German protectorate over Asia Minor, but the increase of German influence in Syria might well be regarded with suspicion by the Power most interested in Egypt.

div.head: BRITISH OFFICERS HELD CAPTIVE
CAPTURED BY BANDITTI
div.p: TANGIER, October 17.
Captain Crowther and Lieutenant Hutton, of the Marines, were captured by the Anghera banditti between Tetuan and here, when re- turning from the stranded repairship Assist- ence.
The object of the capture of Captain Crow- ther and Leutenant Hutton was to compel the authorities to release the chief Valients who is at present imprisoned at Fez (Reuter)
TANGIER, October 17.
The Anghers tribe have captured two British officers in the neighborhood of Ceuta. (Havas)

div.head: FRANCE AND VENEZUALA.
NAVAL DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: CHERBOURG, October 17
A French squadron has left for Venezuelan waters (Reuter)
PARIS, October 17.
The cruiser Desaix has sailed. It is believed that she will make a demonstration against Venezuela. (Havas)

div.head: HUNGARY AND THE CROWN
ACUTE CONFLICT
div.p: BUDAPEST, Octobre 17.
Count Fejervary has been appointed Pre- mire, implying an acute conflict between the Crown and the Parliamentary majority (R.)

div.head: RELEASE OF RUSSIAN WARSHIPS
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, October 17.
The Russian war vessels interned at San Francisco and Cavito have been released (R.)

div.head: THE "ENTENTE MUNICIPALE"
LEVEE AT BUCKINGHAM PALACE
div.p: LONDON, October 17.
The King, attended by the dignitaries of the Court, received the members of the Paris Municipality at Buckingham Palace The levee was most cordial. (Reutier)

div.head: FIGHTING IN SOUTHERN NIGERIA
BRITISH OFFICERS WOUNDED
div.p: LONDON, October 17.
There has been fighting in South- urn Nigeria and three British officers have been wounded. Reinforcements have been sent from Logos. (Reutier)

div.head: THE LATE SIR HENRY IRVING
TO BE BURIED IN THE ABBEY
div.p: LONDON, October 17.
Sir Henry Irving will be buried beside Gar rick in the Poet's Corner of Westminister Abbey. (Reutier)

div.head: COTTON OPERATIVES WAGES
FALL RIVER MANUFACTURERS DECISION
div.p: BOSTON, October 17

The Fall River manufacturers have an- bounced an advance of five per cent in the wages of the cotton operatives, and also a schema for sharing in the profits, which will take effect from the 25th inst. (Reutier)

div.head: ANGLOJAPANESE FESTIVITIES.
div.p: TOKIO, October 17.
The Anglo Japanese festivities here conti- hue to be most enthusiastic. A section of the squadron in being entertained at Nagasaki. (Reutier)

div.head: ANOTHER SUBMARINE DISASTER
EXPLOSION ON BOARD THE A4
div.p: PORTSMOUTH, October 17.

The submarine A4 was towed into the har- hour in a crippled state yesterday evening. This was the result of a slight explosion which occurred as she was rising to the surface. The crew had a bait-breadth escape. The vessel sank this morning, before she could be docked, but there was no body on board. (Reutier)

div.head: STRIKE RIOTS IN RUSSIA
div.p: ST. Petersburg, October 17.
The printers strike here and at Moscow continues. The conflicts are becoming more serious. (Havas)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: THE BRINDISI MAIL will be distributed at the G.P.P, Alexandria, at 5 p.m. to-day.
STRAY DOGS-Stray and ownerless dogs found in Zeitoun during the night of Thursday will be poisoned by the police.
ARMY SCHOOLS- Lieutenant Cooke inspec- tor of Army Schools, has arrived in Cairo from Alexandria and will inspect the English mili- tray schools of the Capital.

"REUNION RAMLISTE"- A group of young men in Ramleh have formed a society, named the "Reunion Ramliste" the object of which is to provide balls and other amusements for its members. Those desirous of joining are requested to communicate with the president of the society, where address is Vila Mar- gherita, San Stefano. The monthly subscrip- tion is, P.T. 10 for single members and P.T. 20 for families.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE- The Octo- her issue of the journal of the British Chamber of Commerce at Alexandria contains some very interesting material, notably an article of British furniture in Egypt which deserve- careful perusal, and which we propose to reproduce in extensor. The trade and financial articles and statistics are as excellent as usual, and some interesting extracts from the railway report help to make up a capital number.

EXCITING OCCURRENCE AT KASR EL NIL About 10 O'clock on Monday night, and unus- ual incident took place at Kar-el-Nil barracks. A soldier, feeling unwell, plunged into the Nile, and commenced swimming away from the bank. Some bystanders at once gave the alarm and several plucky attempts at rescue were made, but the current was strong and the swimmers had some difficulty in regaining the shore, one of them, indeed, being landed in an exhausted condition. Subsequently, a boat was got out and the unfortunate man was pcked up some distance down the river. He was subsequently brought before his commanding officer for absence without leave.

TRAGIC FALL FROM A WINDOW- A horri- blé crime was enacted in the Bab el Sharieh district of Cairo on Monday consequent on a quarrel between a native married couple. It appears that the husband and wife began to struggle with each other, and as they reached the window, the former attempted to throw his wife out of it on the ground many feet below. The woman clung to her husband in an endeavor to save herself, and eventually both of them fell out and were picked up badly injured. The unhappy pair were taken to the Kasr el Aini Hospital, where the woman suc- dumbed in a very short time. It is expected that the husband will recover from his injuries.

"OLD MOORE and Egypt- We reproduce the following prophecy taken from Old Moore's Almanac a titre de curiosité:- "Old Moore has selected a somewhat humorous picture for the month of August- that is to say, the smile is on the side of John Ball. Not withstanding the most enthusiastic mutual good feeling be- tween France and Great Britian, the fact cannot be overlooked that our friends across the Channel have seen with envy the marvelous prosperity that the Government of Great Britain has brought to Egypt, and we may expect about now a movement on the part of France to endeavor to check in some way that money-making monopoly which Mr. Bull holds in the land of the Pyramide." The illustration referred to, which comes under the heading of August, 1906, represents a group of money-laden natives entering an English bank, and John Bull, seated on a camel, being pulled back by the heels by three French soldiers.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: After being received in audience by H.H. the Khedive and having greeted H.E. Mus- tapha Pasha Fehmy on his arrival by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat, Mr. P.W. Machell returned to Cairo from Alexandria last night.
Mr. P.W. Machell's marriage with Countess Victoria Gleichen will take place in December. Mr. Machell will leave Egypt about the ned of November, returning at the end of De- cember.
Count Bolesta de Kosziebrodski, Austro- Hungarian Minister, has returned to Cairo from Europe
Sir Horace Pinching arrives at Cairo on Saturday.
Mr. and Mrs. Lang Anderson and family returned to Alexandria this morning.

Captain H.B.P.L. Kennedy, 1st King's Royal Rifle Coros, and 2nd Leut. A.J. St. G. Loftus, 2nd Rooyal Inniskilling Fusiliers, have been granted sick leave on the recommendation of a medical board and embarked in the trans- port Asaye, at Port Said yesterday, for passage to Southampton.

div.head: RETURN OF LORD CROMER
div.p: Contrary to the announcement which ---- el in the columus of a local contemporary, Lord Cremer did not arrive at Port Said yes- terday by the S.S. Molddavid. Our Port Said Correspondingtelegraphs that his lordship, who embarked at Bindisi on the P. and O. Isis, arrived at Port Said early this morning. A special saloon carriage was in waiting to convey Lord Cromer at Cairo, where he arrived at 1:30 p.m.

div.head: DEATH OF LADY MORICE
div.p: We regret to learn of the death, which oc- cured at Plymouth (England) yesterday, after a protracted illness, of Lady Morice, widow of the late Sir George Morice Pasha.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION
div.p: The following is the order of next Tuesday's reception at Ras-el Tin Palace 9 a.m- The Princess of the Khedivial Familu, the Ulema, the heads of State Admi- nistrations.
At 9.30 a.m- The mixed magistracy, the native magistracy, officers of the army and navy from the rank of Bimbashi and upwards, and the civil officials.
At 10am.- The mixed magistracy, the native magistracy, officers of the army and navy from the rank of Bimbaski and upwards, and the civil officials.

At 10am- Unafficial military and civil personages have the rank of Lewa or Oala Sinf Sani and upwards; officers of the army and navy en disponibite or retired, having the rank of Moralai or Ksimakam; unofficial civil Beys, having the rank of Moutemniz or Sanieh; the members of the Municipal Com- mission.
At 10:30 am- The Diplomatic and Con- sular Corps.
At 10:45 am- Field officeers of the Army of Occupation; the clergy.
At 11 am- Native and European notables and merchants.
The reception is reserved to residents of Alexandria. The military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frock-costa (redingote).

Civil officials admitted to this reception are those having at least the rank of subdirectory or an equivalent rank, and those having at least the grade of Sanieh of Kaimaskam, and magistrates appointed by decree.
The Khedivah will hold a reception at Ras el-Tin Palace on the same day for the Princes- ses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies from 10 to 11.30 am, and for European ladies from 4 to 5 p.m.

div.head: COTTON TRADE WAGES
div.p: In accordance with the terms of settlement if the recent wages dispute in the cotton trade, which provided that the join com- mittee of employers and employed should meet at an early date for the purpose of framing a scheme for the automatic regulation of wages, a meeting was held a few days ago at the offices of the Master Spinners' Federation in Manchester. Representatives of the federa- tion, the Amalgamated Association of Operative Spinners, and the Cardroom Workers' Amalga- nation attended, nut no resolution of import- acne was arrived at. It was felt that before anything practical could be accomplished the representatives of the various organizations should meet separately to consider procedure and other matters. In order that this could be arranged, the meeting was adjourned to a near date.

div.head: THE TRADE OF EGYPT
SEPTEMBER CUSTOMS RETURNS.
div.p: The imports for the past month (inclusive of tobacco) totaled L.E. 1,975,946 against L.E 1,742,088 during the corresponding month of the previous year, showing an in- crease of LE 233,858. For the first nine months of 1905 the value of all imports amounted to L.E. 14,716,859 against L.E. 13,573,380 in the period January 1-Septem- her 30, 1904, an ncrease of L.E 603,912 last moth- a decided drop from the figures of September, 1904 when they amounted to L.E 616,119. Owing no doubt, to the causation of hostilities, imports from China and the Far East show a 13% increase, while Turkish imports have risen from L.E. 280,688 in September, 1904, to L.E. 327,939 last month, and Austria and Sweden show a decided increase. For the nine-months period British imports show an increase of L.E. 282,871, French imports of L.E. 336,167, Turkey and the USA have largely increased their im- ports, and Sweden show an increase of 30%. A decline is noted in German, Italian, and Swiss imports, and in those from India and the Eastern possessions of the British Empire.

Turning to exports, the total for the month amounts to LE 928,302 a fall of L.E. 109,439 as compared to September, 1904. For the first nine months of the present year the total exports are valued at L.E. 12,878,173, against L.E. 13,724,419 in the corresponding period of 1904, showing a decline of L.E. 846,246. Ex- ports to Great Britain fell off for the month and for the first three quarters; the total dimina- tion in value for the last-named period amount- ing to L.E. 520,373. The exports to Italy con- tine to show a falling-off in value, and the only great increase to be noted is in the Amer- I can trade, which shows export figures, this September that more than double those of September, 1904, and has given the remarkable increase on the nine months period of L.E. 333,329. The decrease of exports to Russia is very marked, while British Eastern possessions have nearly doubled their import trade from Egypt.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE SERVICE
div.p: No further details are obtainable concerning the amalgamation of the Hamburg-Amerika Steamship Company and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company. We are informed at the offices of the latter in Cairo that it will be necessary to await the return of the directors from Europe before more de- tails can be learnt, as ply a short telegram announcing the fusion has bee received at the office. The effect of the amalgamation has, however already been felt, and the share of the latter company are quoted at #6, whilst a further and more considerable rise is not unlikely when full details are published. The bookings for the tourists season for the Nile service of this company are excellent, far exceeding those of former years, and the arrangement of the company ensure every comfort and advantage which their clients could wish for.

div.head: TURKISH SPIES IN ALEXANDRIA
div.p: The four Turkish gentlemen wearing Euro- pean clothes and hats, who have recently been haunting the Cafe des Pyramides and dining at the Restaurante Egypte, have left for Smyrna via Athens by the Greek boat. They found that their operations were greatly hampered by the incident curiosity of the public, and that wherever they went they were followed by an admiring crowd, mostly composed of ex- residents of the Asiatic provinces of the Ottoman Empire, whose unseemly levity would have cost them dear in Smyrna Erzeroum, or Beyront. The party, finding themselves too well-known, returned, like Thucydidean armies, having accomplished nothing. We wish good- bye- but not aurevoir- to Rafail Effendi, chief inspector of the Smyrna secret police, Osman Agha, A.D.C. to the Vail of Smyrna, and their two Armenian comrade.

div.head: CAIRO SHOOTING OLTRAGE
HEARING OF WITNESSES
div.p: Carmelo Pissani, a native of Malts, was brought up again yesterday morning before Mr. Alban, at the British Consular Court in Cairo, charged with shooting with intent to murder Victoria Dehan and Austrian subject who had been living with the accused for some time at Port Said.

We related in our issue of Monday how Pisani, when finding that the young woman had left with another lover for Cairo, followed them there, and on discovering their where- a bouts had gone on Friday afternoon to the house situated near Ataba-el-Khadra, and fired at his victim on her refusing to return with him to Port Said. He afterwards turned the weapon on himself, and fired again, causing, however, only a slight wound.

The first witness called was Gaetano Muns- for who disposed as followed, "I am a printer by trade. I saw prisoner on Friday for the first time at about a quarter past three o'clock in the afternoon. I was, then in the office of the 'Imparzale'. I am the proprietor of the print- ing establishment where the paper is printed. Whilst there I heard a revolver shot and went out to see what has happened. I saw the proprie- tress of the lodging house opposite my pace at a window and ward her shouting to me"Help help, as they are killing upstairs." I replied that could not risk my life with people who were armed. I returned to my shop, when I heard another shot. Then, at the request of the land lady of the lodging house, I rant to the end of the street and found a man belong- ing to the fire brigade whom I aroused from sleep. In the meanwhile I heard a third shot at a short interval from the last. The fireman went to the caracole to fetch a policeman whilst I returned to my shop. Then, when entering I saw a woman, who was wounded, coming out of the lodging house and bleeding from the right side. I saw the blood running down her side. Behind the woman I saw the accused also coming dow and covered with blood. He has nothing on his hand. The man wanted to lead back Victoria, but she pushed him away. When he saw that the woman did not wish to go with him Pieani returned to the house. The wounded woman wanted to come into my shop, but I refused her admittance." On Mr. Alban here mentioning that he thought this conduct inhuman the witness explained that he did not want her to come into the shop by the front and asked her to go to the workshop at the back to prevent a crown collecting, and anything disagreeable occurring with the police.

The witness continued: "After a little while some policemen arrived and commenced to hold an enquiry. None of these policemen dared to go in, but remained outside. In the meanwhile the accused came down with his hat on and a flu-whisk in his hand. Pirani walked quietly away, the policeman following. When the accused stopped and looked round the two policemen courageously got out go the way (great laughter). The crowd, on seeing this kept calling out "Arrest the man, he did the deed." They, however, kept at a safe distance. The fireman called by me afterwards took hold of the prisoner, seizing him by both arms. He was then conducted to the caracole. Later there arrived the chief of the secret police, the mamour of the district, and some other people, and Victoria then returned to the house where she lived. When the woman went back her second lover, named Giorgio came, and on being told that his signora was wounded he ran upstairs. I got to know that his man on seeing a revolver upstairs came down again and ran away as fast as he could go. Shortly after the wounded woman was brought down, put into a carriage and driven away. After about half an hour she returned to the house with an Arab. I led her upstairs. On my coming out I met the accused, who had been brought back to the house, accom- panned bu the police, I asked him whether this woman was his wife or his sister. He answered "No". I then asked him how those wounds had been inflicted. He replied "I don't know. I heard two shots but I don't know where they came from." There was a revolver lying on the table, and on being asked by the mamour if it belonged to him Pisani said it was not his.

In no answer to a question from his Honor, the witness declared there was an interval of about five minutes between each shot. The second witness was Rosine Krauss, an Austrian subject, who is the keeper of the lodging-house. The woman deposed that Victoria came with a man called Giorgio Mascarelli about two months ago and the repre- sensed themselves as husband and wife. On the 11th the accused knocked at her door just before noon. In reply to her enquiry Pisani said he wanted to see a certain Victoria Dehan. She told him she knew no person of that name. He added that he had come from Port Said on behalf of the consulate. The accused then left. Witness afterwards went to Victoria's room and told her what had happened. She looked out of the window, and on seeing her Pisani return- ed to the house and again knocked at the door, but Victoria begged witness not to open. Then accused forced the door open and came in. Subsequently he went out with Victoria. About 3.30 p.m. the latter returned with her supposed husband. Last Friday afternoon the accused called again and an altercation ensued, the upshot of which was the he drew a revolver and shot his ex-paramour, while she and her mother (who had meantime put in an appear- acne) were sitting on chair in the parlor. After some more confirmatory evidence had been heard, prisoner was remanded until Monday morning, when the remaining witnesses will be examined. His Honor intimated that he would consider the application for bail on Saturday.

div.head: A SPORTING TRIP.
E.T.C. MEET AT SUBS
div.p: Last Friday, on the invitation of the Suez E.T.C. Cricket Club and Mess, a team of eleven representing the Alexandria staff of the same company left by the 3.40 p.m. train, arriving at the Suez at 11.30 p.m. Although cricket was the main object of the trip, tennis (singles and doubles), a relay billiard math, and a golf match were all fixed up before- hand. On Saturday, at about 10.45, a start was made at cricket in very hot weather (during the match the thermometer restored 95 degrees in the shade). R.B. McLean won the toss and put in Suez in Maynard and Carpenter open- ed against the bowling of Byrne and Thurston. The wicket was not at its best and the outfield very rough and slow, so that scoring was a matter of some difficult. Byrne im- mediately found his length and throughout was almost unplayable, accounting for eight of the wickets for thirteen runs (7 clean bowled) -a most excellent bowling performance. The remaining two Suez men were run out. More of them should have suffered this fate had the Alexandria throwing in been more accurate as Suez ran some very risky runs. Maynard played a very steady innings, as did Masey. Noe- worthy livened things up a bit and showed how to score in desert cricket by hitting "hard and high", though fortunately for Alexandria not "often". The total reached 72, - much better one than it looked and quite equal to 180 on the Alexandria ground. The lunch interval was taken with the fall of the last Suez wicket, and the game resumed at 2 o'clock. Stacey and Cheeseman opened for Alexandria to the bowl- ing of Mansell and Noseworthy, and the score mounted steadily until, with the total at 15, Stacey was bowled by Nosworthy. Cheesman and Byrne put on 25 for the third wicket, and after Cheesman left with a most useful 21 to his credit, McLean's anxiety to score more freely brought about his downfall. During the partnership the winning hit was made. Byrne did not long survive McLean, being bowled by Battiscombe for a somewhat lucky but invaluable 38. After his departure there was a comparative collapse, the remaining five wickets only producing 16 runs. G. McLean in his nine had a brace of very big hits which would have credited him with a dozen in Alex- andria. The total reached 116. Score and analysis:-

As the cricket finished soon after 4 o'clock an adjournment was made to the tennis courts -of which there are three in excellent condi- tion-and the others McLean opened the tennis camp in with a match against Mesers. Quintana and Pittuck. The Alexandira pair proved the strongest and won by 6-3, 6-4.

At 8 o'clock a company of over forty, includ- ing both teams, the staff of the cabeship Duplex, and the other members of the Suez mess, sat down to dinner in the speeded dining-room of the staff mess and passed a most pleasant hour and a half until speech time. The toast list was made as short as possible in order to allow of a start being made in the billiard match. Harrison for "Alex." started with Toms and, playing an uphill game nearly all through, reached 100 to his opponent's 96. G. McLean then took up the one for Alexandria and Templeman for Suez. This, too was very close and they were 180 all when McLean put in a twenty break and gave Byrne, who relieved him, this balance in hand. Mansell, who was his opponent could not get going, the balls running most unkindly, while Byrne went steadily on, with the result that Alexandria reached 300 to Suez's 237. R.B. McLean, with Marx of Suez, then entered on the final stage of the match, but Marx was given too heavy a task, and Alexandria won the match by 400 to 317.
Next morning the gold match was played, and in this Suez scored their first success. Noe- worthy beat Byrne by three and two, and Toms beat Harrison by three up.
Next morning the golf match was played, and in this Suez scored their first success. Noe- worthy beat Byrne by three and two, and Toms bat Harrison by three up.

In the afternoon the remaining tennis match- es came off, and Suez won two of the four. Blythman beat Mansell 2 sets to 1. Byroe lost to Quintana 1 set to 2. Blythman and Byrne best Mansell and Mudge 2 sets to love. Cheesman and Henley lost to H. R. Harris and Menzies love to 2 sets. Alexandria there- fore won by 7 sets to 3, 60 games to 31 and 3 matches to 2. This brought the series of match- es to an end and the result was very satis- factory to the visitors. The Alexandria men were the guests of the Suez mess and were treated right royally, enjoying their trip im- mensely. Hopes were freely expressed of a return fixture and of the mateb being an annual one. The Railway Administration de- serve mention for their very sporting assist- acne in giving a considerable reduction in the railway fare. Part of the Alexandria team returned on Sunday and the rest on Monday.

The "Times" contains the following article from correspondent Alexandria Anyone who has followed closely the laws enacted of late years in Egypt cannot fail often to notice in them a lack of business foresight. I am now dealing with one of the laws which never fails to raise grave complaints on all hands in Egypt and which since its birth has been the cause of great dissatisfaction. This is the now famous law on the "Concordat Pre ventif." The measure appears to have taken its origin from the French law of Match 4, 1839, on the "Liquidation Jadiciairt,” and imperfect as this law has been pronounced to be, the Egyptian law on the’ “conoordat Pre ventif” is very much worse. One market consequence of the law is that the number of failures had decreased and the number of admitted to the benefit of the "Conbordat Preventif” has been steadily on the increase.

THE LEGISLATURE AND BANKRUPTCY To the Egyptian legislator it seemed that the time had come to admit that in Egypt there were merchants and traders who, through misfortunes altogether independent of any fault of theirs, had fallen into commercial trouble. But the legislator apparently lost sight, of the fact that half at least of these worthy , merchants would be natives whoso ways of trading and ideas of commercial order were but little known to him. It was not realised that the social opprobium from which the “Concordat Preventif’ was intended to save tho unfortunate and innocent traders’ was of no great moment to the native mer- chant ; bankruptcy indeed has not the same moral and social consequences, even to European in Egypt, that it has in Euro pean countries. Thus the reason which led to the enactment of the French law on the '‘Liquidation Jud ciaire" did not seem to exist in Egypt; and in fact what Egypt required were more stringent and severe laws dealing with failures and bankruptcies, and not a law which has afforded a wider field than existed before to unscrupulous merchants and their creditors for fraudulent mareuvers to the detriment of honest traders.
The French Liquidates Judiciaire.”
M. Demole in his report to tho French Senate on tho "Loi de la Liquidation Judi ciaire" explained the object of the law when he said:-

This new regime, which is reserved for debt- ors unfortunate and of good faith, and which adjusts the law, as iar as convenient, for the regulation of their business, would free those debtors from the sharp humiliations and harsh treatment which accompany the state of bank ruptcy. This law would, in the interest of creditors, simplify the preliminary operation of settlement and arrive sooner and with les expense either at the ‘conoordat' (composition) or the liquidation of the assets. But [he con- tinued], in order that a merchant could claim the application of the benefit of the new law, it is necessary that the Courts, called upon always to judge the merchant's position, should not find in the conduct of his business either bad faith or any one of those serous faults which prove on the part of him who committed them wilful disregard of his own responsibilities That is the object of proposing this law. It most be borne in mind that this French law was the result of much criticism adverse to the law of May 28, 1838, which dealt severely with all bankruptcy. A similar thing cannot be said of the application of the former Egyptian law on bankruptcy ; in fact, such as it was, it was a good law, and all it required was that criminal jurisdiction should be given to the Mixed Courts over cases of fraudulent and simple bankruptcies. These extended powers of the Mixed Courts would have been the means of impressing prospective bankruptcy with the fear of a stricter and more effective law than the old 'one, which deferred criminal proceedings against the bankrupt to the Con sular Court, with the result that scarcely ever if at all, was the matter extended beyond mere complaint made to the Consular autho rity.
WORKING OF THE "CONCORDAT PREVENTI

It has been contended that the law on the "Concordat Preventif' is a good law. I have already said that in practice it is most un satisfactory, as it is also in its conception, and if that contention were justified, then this law either is not strictly applied by the Courts whose business it is to apply it, or else it con- tains something which diverts its aim. I am afraid that both those things are responsible for the dissatisfaction felt with the law. The operation of tbs law is as follows : — The would be commercial malheureux et de bonne Joi files a declaration of insolvency in the registry Of the Court accompanied by his balance sheet; he may or he may not deposit his books; very seldom he does. At the first sitting of the Court after the filing of the declaration, the matter is brought forward; no notice is given to the creditors and the Court begins by delivering a judgment admitting the declarant to the benefit of the “Concordat Preventif’-under the circumstances, of course, with out a dis- sentient voice. Once proclaimed a malheureux et de bonne foi Article 206 enacts that the Court shall appoint one of the judges, “who will sign the books of the debut and who will proceed to verify the situation .... and will convene a meeting of the creditors before him with a view to learning their opi nion on the admission to this Concordat Pre- ventir and will read to the meeting a report on the good faith of the debtor, his buisness position, and his proposals for a composition. The Judge, of course, appoints an expert of the Court to overband the books and examine all papers, and it is he who makes out the report. If the debtor succeeds in obtaining a majority representing three-fourths of his crediitors claims he is entitle to the concordat ; but This concordat” must be homologated-or confirmed by the Court. Here the creditor! it tho minority are given a chanoe of oppAinf the “concordat," and the Court itself by the operation of Article 260 may at any moment. if it becomes convinced that the debtor is not malreuAeux et ce bonne foi, declare him bank- rupt moreover, the “concordat” remains subject to the provision of Article 1341 and 312 of the Commercial Cole in case of fraud as therein mentioned or of non fulfilment of the condition of the "concordat."
DEFECTS IN PRACTICE

No doubt to the uninitiated these legal pre cautions may appear a sufficient guarantee ; unfortunately they are ineffective,for it is found in practice that the law has put the cart before to the horse. Indeed, what the law asks is that the debtor be declared malheurenx el de bonne foi on his own affirmation, and that is con- sidered sufficient to begin with. Then his itaation is investigated, and when this is done the creditors are asked to come and prove that the debtor is not maUteureux el de bonne foi. It would seem for all logical purposes that the reverse should happen. It would be more rational if the Court were, on the declaration made by the debtor, to appoint at once an expert who would report to the Court on the situation and circum- stances of the insolvency, give notice of the deposit of the report and the books and all papers at the registry to tho creditors, and then fix a day for the creditors to appear in Court and put forward their observations. The full Court would then give their judg- ment with complete knowledge of the case. As now happens the fall Court hears the minority of the creditors after the majority has already confirmed-by its vote the provi- ional admission of the debtor to the benefit w of the ““Concordat Preventil,” which is a totally different thing. The Judge appointed by the Court leaves everything in the hands of the expert, who in practice not being invest- ed, as in the case of a bankruptcy, with the power of a syndic, must often simply give an account of the position, seldom trou- bling himself except in patent cases with giving an opinion as to tho good faith of the debtor. On the other hand, there being no supervision whatever over the creditors—by_a committee of creditors — the- -greatest abuses are most frequently committed ; personal ad- li vantages are distributed by the debtor, and when, on paper, it appears to the Court that the debtor offers, say. 40 per cent.) one or more creditors have actually received an extra 10 per cent or more, according to their importance and their ingenuity in extorting all they can out of their unscrupulous debtor. The majority required by the law is thus obtained; the Court’s practice almost invariably follows the of vote; and Article 210 is and remains a dead letter for an upright creditor unless he can make tho Court acquire the conviction that the debtor is not “anfortunate and of good faith.” But in order to do so he must bring nothing short of palpable proof of fraudulent bankruptcy, and that is not an easy matter. Many circumstances may concur to show the absence of good faith on the part of the debtor, which will, however, fall short of fraudulent bankruptcy; yet, although the |aw does— not require as much, the Courcs satisfy themselves, nevertheless, with a majority of votes, unless, as Isay, there can be made out a crashing in case against the debtor
PlAYING WITH THE LAW.

The result of all this is that the law has become a most convenient means whereby a man may enrich himself. And naturally so, for on the one hand the expert is a mere inoffensive instrument; and as he has no power worth mentioning, he counts for very little indeed, and in practice he confices himself strictly to his ludicrous mission. On the other hand the creditors are easy prey; and the debtor can do anything he likes with them; the obstreperous minority is not to be feared, for the Court follows the majority. Moreo ve there is, it seems, no appeal against the judg- ment confirming or homologating the decision of the majority of the creditors. What could be better for the debtor And let us bear in mind that the object of the law is to save the trader the moral pain and social opprobrium following upon a declaration in bankruptcy, and also save the creditors expense by amelior- atiag tho proceedings and simplifying the legal process! The debtor has turned all this to his advantage, and it has often been seen that on the following day after his "concordat” has been ratified he opens a larger shop, better equipped, and supported by the credit of bis former creditors. And why so I Because in most cases his creditors are the agents of European firms, to whom their representatives in Egypt give the 40 per csnt. or mere 15 per cant, appearing on paper for the “conoordat," while they pocket quietly the extra 5 per cent, 10 per cent., or 20 cent. according to circumstances, and in consideration of which they have recommended to their firms in Europe the acceptance of the “conoordat” and the continuance of supplies of goods when the debtor is whitewashed by the majority of his creditors.

It has, indeed, been asserted that the Frenoh law on the "Liquidation Judicair” is no better. This is wrong; that law is bad, but it is better than the one in Egypt. Article 4 of the French law enacts that the full Court, in Chambers, shall summon before it the debtor and examine him, which is something akin to our examination in England by the registrar and the official reciever. The debtor has to explain his position to the Court before it provisionally pronounces its opinion. The report on the law to the French Senate set forth plainly :—"We thought it was not sufficient to make the appearance of the debtor before the full Court optional; in chambers we made it compulsory." Moreover, Article 9 of the law enacts that the Judge shall ask the cre- ditor whether they will appoint a few amongst them to control the work of the liquidator There is no such provision in the Egyptian law.

div.head: MISSIONS IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: A PIONEER EXPEDITION.

Reuter’s Agency is informed that an im- portant missionary pioneer expedition to the Sudan is being depatched by the Church Missionary Society this month. The sphere of work has been selected by the Earl of Cromer, and comprises a region about four times the size of England, inhabited by pagan tribes, the majority of whom are men of immense stature, and some of whom are cannibals. Roughly speaking, it will start from the junction of the Sobat and Bahr-el-Ghazal rivers, and stretch- ing on both sides of the Nile will extend to the northern border of Uganda and the north- east comer of the Congo Free State. Running along the northern part of Lake Rudolph, it will include the south-western boundary of Abyssinia. The region is largely one of sudd and swamp, being intersected by the Upper Nile, which will form tho principal route of communication.

It is only now, when, in the opinion of Lord Cromer and the Sirdar,the political and general situation warrants it, that it is found possible to reply to an appeal for a mission in this region which was made by General Gordon nearly thirty years ago. The mission will link up Egypt aid Uganda. The first party,' consisting of six mission aries, will leave Marseilles on the 18th inst by the German steamer Schleswig, and hope to reach the scene of their labours by Christmas. They take provisions for twelve months, and expect to live for a considerable period in boats and tents. At Cairo, after conferring with Lord Cromer, they will proceed to Khar toum, whence they will travel by sailing boats, which will be acquired by tho mission, for about 1,100 miles np the White Nile. Escorted by Arch lesson Gwyone of Khartoum, they will first go right through the new district to its most southerly point at Mongalla, a Government' station, near the borders of the headquarters of the mission will be fixed near This point the only other habitable place being Bir situatedon the line some distance to the north of Lido. Tho Pagan tribes inhabiting this region include the Nuers, Dinks, Shilluks, Baris, and Niam Niams. The whole of the vast areahassuffered considerably from Dervish raids, but the natives are now regaining confi dence.

An addition to the clergy who go with the pioneers, the party includes a doctor from Poplar Infirmary, a carpenter from one of the County Council technical schools, and an an agricultural expert. After escorting them to Mongalla, where they will be met by Dr. da A. R. Cook, of the Uganda yission, who still have medical supervision, for six months, Arohdeacon Gwayne will return to his work at Khartoum. It is is tended at first to commence industrial work among the pagans, and in time teach them to manufacture bricks. It is hoped that a second party will be despatched 1 from England in July, and a third next autumn. Tho region indicated by Lord Cromer was specially selected, so that the work in view du would not touch tho Mohamedan population, and would not clash with the spheres occupied by the Americans on the Sobat, and by the Austrian Roman Catholic Mission. In in- dicating the new sphere to the Church Missionary Society, Lord Cromer says: “It is bounded, on the north by the Bahr- ar el Ghazal, on the east by a line proceeding south from the White Nile, starting at a point about half-way between where the Nile is joined by the Bahr-el Zaraf, and where it is joined by the Gahr el-Jebel to Ajiung, and thence southwards to Twi. From Twi the line proceeds due east to the Abyssinian frontier and thence follows the frontier to the Uganda border on tho fifth parallel of North Latitude. On the south it is bounded by the northern do border Qf the Congo Free State, the Lado en- clave, and the Uganda province; on the west, by a line drawn from Marhre-el-Rek to a point where the frontiers of the Congo Free State, the French’Grugftand the Bahr el Ghazal meet near N'Darama.
Toe pioneer party consists of the Rev. F. B. fou Hadow, the Riv. A. Shaw, the Rev. A. M. Thorn, Dr. E. Lloyd, and Messrs. J. Comely and I R 0. J. S. Wilmot.

div.head: MATTERS OF MOMENT.
div.p: PITH OF THE PRESS COMMENTS
ASIA AND THB ANGLO-JAPANB8B TREATY.
“Times."

The public are confident that the Agree ment will prove a bulwark of the peace Asia for many years to come. .... We may admit at once that treaties made on eqna terms between one Great Power and anothe; have their disadvantages as well as theii advantages, like most other human arrange ments. Bet the prejudice whicn condemn.- treaties in principle upon this ground is in dotd old-fashioned. It depends on a conception of foreign politics which never was altogethei correct, and which the modem developments ol WiUpolitik have rendered quite out of date. ......All the Great Powers now have in- terests and aspirations in parts of Asia elsewhere where our interests are Vital. All of them believe in alliances and are actually in aihancos, or ready to enter into alliances, for various objects. Isolation in these condi- tions spells weakness, mid weakness, in the case of a Power so wealthy as ourselves, is an invitation to aggression, the only method ol preserving the peace of Asia is to confront any ambitions directed against it by the ready arms of a coalition too strong to be defied. Our Treaty with Japan Las established soob i coalition, and has mado peace secure in the only way by which it could be made secare. ENGLAND, FRANCE AND GERMANY.

div.head: Daily Tklkghapu.
div.p: There is only one moral to bo derived from tho acrimonious controversy arising out of the revelations of oertain ol our Paris contempora- ries, and that is that diplomatists should only talk to one anotber.When the Foreign Ministei of one country unbosoms himself to tfewspapei correspondents of another on matters of imme diate or recent negotiations, recriminations are certain to follow. Lately thero has been a riotous outburst of confidences of this perilous nature ; Priuoe Buelow, Count Witte, and the inspirer of the articles in the "Matin" have talked openly upon subjects that should only ba diacussd in the strictest privacy . . . . We regret that Prinoo Buelow should bavi given provocation, and that M. Delcaasd —if hi has really inspired the "revelations"—should have taken up the challenge. Who profits by these disclosure* 1 If they are not based upor fact, no words can be too strong to condemi their fabrication. If they are substantially true the whole story is known already to thosi principally concerned, who have oome to at arrangement which it is nobody's interest disturb.

div.head: Standard
div.p: It has always been the wish of the Boglisl Government and people to live on good termi with Germany. We are oonacioue of no enmity towards the Fatherland, and our only rivalry lies in the honorable field of commercial com- petition. Nor shall we allow our polioy to b« altered, our judgment disturbed, or even oui temper ruffled by the angry and ill-informed comments of oertain German pubdeists on the reoent action of Great Britain in regard to French rights in Morooco. We regret to ob- serve, however, that a hectoring tone has been taken up by journals which have hitherto ob served a judicious moderation in their attitude toaarda ourselves. It is not difficult to account for the irritation which they display. They art uncomfortably consoious that the national diplomacy bas met with a sudden and very nuplcasant check.................... Every State fir itself—that is the Gerrman motto,and the sufficient answer is,“Forewarned forearmed." Nevertheless the conspicuous fail of Berlin, in this instance as in others proceeds from its insensibility to the feelirgi of nstions. Individually, the German is by nr means harsh or selfish, bat the action of bii Government is deplorably lacking /in regari for tbe finer feelings of humanity.

div.head: "Daily News
div.p: On the whole the German Press takes th sensible attitude of icredality in regard the latest journalistic sensation in Prmaqe. greatly admire the enteiprise-of the Matin in many respects ; but it is not precisely th sort of journal to which we look for -vmviiiam revelations. It loves, like onr own ';Matio, to make onr flesh creep, and in the word, this startling story of the secret history Of Europe has fallen on incredulous ears.

div.head: "Westminster Gazette"
div.p: There are, of course, moments in French diplomacy when the idea of an Anglo German rapprochement it inconvenient to France but for permanent purposes France cannot pat herself into the hands of any partner who is not, in the case of a quarrel, exposed To the same liability as herself, the liability of invasion. This is bound to be the Case for quite obvious and elementary reasons, though some of anti-Germans seem to have great difficulty in understanding it.

div.head: "Evening Standard”
div.p: No useful purpose can concavely be Served by taking up the challenge of the Ger- man Press to indulge in mutual recrinations or on paper. It is easy to understand that the German nation and the German Government are in a state of high tension and suffering from a bad attack of "nerves." That was already the oase beforo the alleged revelations of the "Matin" found their way to print. And now the official communique which graces the German Press does its best to make the trouble worse. Its language is pompous, and therefore absurd. To reply to it in kind would a be loss of dignity and common sense. But the whole incident shows how "blazing" are the at indiscretions of to-day. How sober and re- sponsible Ministers such as Prince von Buelow (The fount and origin of the trouble) and M. Delcaise (the supposed inspirer of the ^ "Matin") can venture to play with fire as they have been doing, and continue to do, passes the ordinary comprehension.

div.head: "Temps"
div.p: An Anglo French alliance, destined, whether 30 desired or not, to arouse keen anxiety in Ger- many, would be a source of great strength for England. It would not, however, be a source er of strength for France. British friendship is precious to us, and we wish to preserve it. The rapprochement it useful to us and we intend to safeguard it. An alliance, on the other hand, would be a cause of disturbance in Europe which, while compromising us, would in case of a conflict famish as with no sufficient guarantee. Our natural position and our per- manent interest is to be the allies of Rossia and the friends of England and Italy. . . If conflicts, which we do not consider inevitable and which we shall contribute to avert in the higher interest of civilisation, should unfor- tinnately break on, our army and navy should have no other mission in a difference occurring in which we had no concern than to safeguard is, the independence of one soil and of oar policy. se Apart from the Russian alliance, French policy in is and ought to remain one of courteous to autonomy.

div.head: "Cologne Gazette."
div.p: If the account published by the "Matin” were tree, it would represent nothing elethan n* a terrible exposure of M. Delcasse’s policy, which could, according to this account, have had no other object than a conflict between Germany and France We are not inclined to believe that England, without any out ward cause, came to the support of M. Delcasse with an offer of military assistance. Assuming the truth of the story, it is much more probable that M Delcaasl, when he found himself in a Could de sac with his Morocco policy, saw no way except war, and that be applied to Eng- land for military support This would con- clusively prove that M. Dekassl had brought France to the edge of war, and that the pro- Action of his policy would very probably have al ended in war—a war which we are convinced the vast majority of the French people as little desired as Germany desired it.

div.head: "VOSSISCHE ZEITUNO.
div.p: Are the “Matin’s" revelations true or on- Truth. If founded on fact, they provide an as explanation of the rumours circulated some Time ago that the German navy was preparing for war against England. If the revelations bo based on truth, the re-organisation of the British Navy and other events would appear in quite a different light from that in which they have bitterroot been regarded. It would be perfectly clear that it is not Germany who has evil designs against England, but England who has hostile designs against Germany. Why, What injury has Germany done Great Britain which justifies the British Government’s re- Live to assist France in a war against Ger- Many.

div.head: THE CRETAN INSURRECTION
div.p: ENGLISHMAN’S EXPERIENCES.

Mr. Charles H. Hawes, who has returned to England after four months scientific tour in Crete, undertaken for the purpose of anthropo- logical research in connection with the arebaso- logioal excavations, said in the course of an interview.

"From Canea I pushed on direct for the chief camp of the insurgent host at Therisso. It is a poor mountain village, though rich for the Cretans in historical associations. Its scat Tired cottages are uuite unlike the packed villages of Eeast and Central Crete, rising roof above roof in terraces. Therisso live in a hollow nearly 1,900 ft. above the sea, and is approached by one pass through an olive grove. From the bills above can be described the capital, Canea, with the foreign battleships lying at anchor. No sentinels were posted as I and my servant rode op announced, but groups of armed men stopped to stare at' us. About a score, rifles in hand, were seated at the Kaffen- cion, and finally we were brought up by five burly fellows, including, I believe, the captain- general of the forces, who inquired whence I came and whither I went I made my way to a the Megan, a wooden shanty, where the pro- printer, girded with cartridge belt and pistol, his gun on the wall handy, was doing, a roar- Ing trade in bread and cheese, boiled gherkins, fried potatoes, lemons, wine, ‘mastics,’ and the occasional luxury of a bit of meat oat from the car case banging at the door. It was a curious sight at evening, the groups of leaders—lawyers and doctors—in rough dress, -eating their simple fare seated at tables, improvised from planks and boxes, under the olive trees from which swung an oil lamp or two; and ever and anon numbers of the rank and file in their Cretan costume of .'.braided waistcoat, baggy breeches, each and top boots, moved to and fro with an occasional thud of the rifle butt, for none would let hie gun out of his hands. These included severe gendarmes, of whom | about sixty had gone over to the revolutionists, 1 During the day the leaders wore occupied in the discussions, occasional harangues, and the arrangement of the movement of the bands. The men themselves, who renewed sixpence Per day pay were mostly engaged in playing cards. backgammon or sitting chatting outside the Kaffection. Owing to tho kindness of one of the leaders, M. Manos, who I discovered was a graduate of Balliol, I was able to make craniometrical observations on most of assembled warriort.”

div.head: ATTACKED BY BRIGANDS
div.p: “From Theridio I continued my journey to- wards Shakia, that province which stood more or less successfully conquerors of Crete, and the home of political revolutions. I had been warned of the difficulties of the route itself, and was mors impressed by the drop of 3,100 ft. from the plain of Omalos (4,000ft.) to the torrent bed below, than by anything similar in the Himalayas or the billy regions of Ceylon. My servant and I were with difficulty getting the mules down this precipit- ion side of the great gorge when we Were am- bushed by two armed men, wild shepherd folk from the mountains. I was absolutely unarmed and rather taken aback when my servant called to me in Creek : 'They are going to fire, sir, and, looking up, beheld two mu ales pointed at me at a distance of about a down yards. It was money they wanted ; a hundred napoleons (£80) they demanded; but as I was not inclin- ed to negotiate and it was impossible to escape, I adopted the obvious alternative and continu- ed the difficult dat cant It was slow work, and after a few yards calls, followed by stones and then ballets, were sent after me. The first four shots were wide and three times the men dam- be red down to get nearer aim, and with better effect, for the last six fractured rocks at my elbow, and the splinters brushed my forehead. Thair sh ieling was oertainly bad, bnt then in none of the encounters with the International troops have the insurgents displayed their boasted gtod marksmanship. My servant had been swearing in Greek daring this time that we had no money, and with some effect, for my ssiailants now demanded the mules and the baggage. Finally after sundry disputes and renewals of our journey they brought their demands down with Oriental suddenness to From which I met with an offer of 10fr. Unfor- tunately my servant, who was ahead, was made to discharge his purse, the other robber mean while covering me with his rifle at six yards and daring me to move. Ultimately we got rid of them, and two and a half hours of rocky descent and fordings of the torrent brought us to the poor little hamlet of Samaria."

div.head: ATTITUDE OF THE POWERS.
div.p: "On tho general condition of the country the state of political suspense has had most unfortunate results. Capital is shy, industry has suffered, and life and property are unsafe, After the Powers had categorically refused, on to May 13, the request of the Chamber for union in with Greece, the insurgents adopted a more energetic propaganda, and the seizure of the town of Vamos was followed in July by the capture of local customs houses. Encounters bad so far been mainly convinced fined to Venezelo’s followers and the gendarmes and foreign troops. Now they are taking place between civilians, those — the great majority—who favor union and those whose interest it la to keep in with the present Government. This is a very serious development. At first the Powers treated the insurrection as a mere outbreak of a dissatisfied party and failed to Attach importance to the history of the last New year. During this period education, lan- guage, commerce, and general communications have been so many links in tho chain binding Crete to Greece, and instead of dealing with a Few armed bands led by burgry politician, the Protecting Powers find themselves face to face With a strong national majority whoM latent power will be sufficient to prolong the struggle. At the outset I was loth to contemplate Crete joining Greece, the material disadvantages to the former were obvious. 'Why no, said I to many a village politician, 'gradually develop a real autonomy but after journeying all over the island and meeting all classes of people, I from shepherds to Dr. Sphakianakis himself, am convinced that outside the Mussulmans nine-tenths of the Cretans favor anion with Greece, and that the material disadvantages do not weigh with the racial feeling. Perhaps only the educated realise the former, bat they are quite prepared to face them. There is another reason, practical rather than senti- mental, which I do not find mentioned, bat which continually came op in quiet talks with villagers—that it the fear of annexation by one of the crest Powers. Soda Bay is a tempt- ing harbour, and if yon refer to the solemn declaration of the Protecting Powers on this point, the Cretan quietly and tersely comments

div.head: 'Egypt and Manchuria.’
div.p: The protecting Powers are faced with an increasingly awkward situation caused by Prince George's failures in a very difficult position, their own procrastination, and the political rivalry among the Cretans. As known to me there were in July last only two bases— and these were considerable compromises—on which the insurgents would treat One was the impossible coup d/tat of Prince George going over to their camp, and the other the appointment of an experienced Greek admi- nistrator in place of Prince George, who could be trusted not to violate the censtitation. This, on the understanding that anion should ultimately take place. This is as far as the Cretan insurgents would go, but the difficulties in the way of acceptanoe by the Powers have relation to Prince George and his connection to the crowned beads of Europe. The Athenian papers which clamper for union would regard Prince George’s return as a disgrace, which would refleet in a u-nature upon the Greek Royal Family. Moreover, Prince George was the nominee of the Emperor of Russia and the companion of his travel in the Far Bast Here, then, is a deadlock out of which who shall deliver the Cretans"

div.head: THE TSETSE FLY.
div.p: Since the days of Dr. Livingstone, the tsetse fly has been known as constituting one of the greatest difficulties of African travel in many regions. It renders thousands of square miles of ’hat country uninhabitable, and (says the “Globe") neither horses, cattle, nor dogs can venture into the ‘ fly country.”Formerly it was thought that the fly injected poison into the animals, and so killed them. It is now known, however, that the diseare is due to a minute blood parasite, a tscrewshaped organism known as trypanosoma, and that the fly only acts as a carrier. There parasites swim freely in the blood, and often number several mil- lions in every drop. It is a very remarkable fact that among the many blood sucking flies. which exist in Africa, the tsetse (Glossina monitans) is the only one capable of convey- ing the parasite from a diseased to a healthy animal. And the explanation of this is that the parasite has the power of multiplying in the body of this, and probably not is other flies. The former, at any rate, has been demonstrated recently by Messrs. Gray and Tulloch, two Army medical officers, who have been studying “sleeping sickness” in Uganda. Another curious fact is that tsetse flies brought directly from the "fly country,” where there is do disease, and allowed to bite healthy, cattle, at once produce the disease. This has led to investigations, which have shown that most of the wild animals of the country, buf- falo, koodoo, carry small numbers of try- panosomas in their blood. These organisms, which multiply to such an enormous extent in the blood of domestic animals, and produce such disastrous effects, can live in small num- bers in the blood of wild animals without any ill result. In a similar way, the trypanosome discovered by Surgeon-Major Lewis in India in the blood of healthy rats, nausea a fatal, disease in horses and dogs. This accounts for the fact that the test fly disease disappears from a district as soon as the wild killed iff, or driven away. At present, then, the extermination of the wild game seems to be the only practical method for exterminating the disease.

That dread disease of the human subject, the “sleeping sickness," is similar in its origin to the tsetse fly decrease of cattle. It is caused that is to say, by a species of trypanosome in the blood, aid conveyed from one subject to another by a specie) of tsetse-fly, "Glossina palpalis." And as the parasite of the cattle disease exists in small number in the blood of healthy wild animals, so this latter,trypanesa- probably occurs in some other species in a similar way. The discovery of this natural reservoir of the parasite would be a step towards the extermination of the dread "sleep- ing sickness."

div.head: MACEDONIAN BRIGANDAGE.
div.p: THE BRITISH CAPTIVE.

Some information regarding Mr. Philip Wills, the English gentleman whose fate it for the moment matter of grave concern to the British Consular. officials in Macedonia, has been received by Reuter's Agency. Hr. Graves, the Consul General at Salonika, left on the 6th inst. for Moaastii; end it is believed that his journey were prompted by the receipt of a cut-off ear together with a letter affirming that it had been severed from the bead of Mr. Wills, who was detained prisoner by brigands, and for whose release a ransom of £6.000 must be paid before the 14th last. Mr. Wills was captured by bandits in the district of Monastir about the middle of July while ont shooting. About a fortnight later a body was found near Ochrida, and it was declared that it was that of Mr. Wills. A week later Hilmi Pasha, the Turkish Inspector General in Macedonia, gave notice that the report of his death was an tree, and that lit. Will* bed Joined a Greek bend. It was not until the beginning of September that the troth leaked oat. Definite information was then received that Mr. WiHr was alive bat was the prisoner of the tend of brigands. Mr. Wills is about 37 years of age. He is the eon of an engineer who was for many years engaged in work In Turkey, and is the brother of the British Consoler Agent at Ismid Al- ways of an adventurous disposition, he volun- teered for service with the British Army in the South African War. While in South Africa however, he was thrown from his horse, and being invalided home, returned to Turkey, where, through the influence of relatives, be obtained an appointment with the Turkish Tobaccor Regia.

It is thought highly probable that the ear which has been sent to the British Consulate at Salonika is not really that of Mr. Wills, but has been sent with the idea of bringing pres- sure to tear in order the better to ensure the payment of the ransom demanded. Those who are acquainted with affairs in Macedonia do not think that the sum named (£6,000)is greater than the brigade are likely to claim as on previous occasions soma no less con- s id stable have been demanded as the ransom for the captives of bandits.
